Issues.Title: fix(ivy): correctly resolve shorthand property declarations
Issues.Body:
The partial evaluator in ngtsc can handle a shorthand property declaration
in the middle of evaluation, but fails if evaluation starts at the shorthand
property itself. This is because evaluation starts at the ts.Identifier
of the property (the ts.Expression representing it), not the ts.Declaration
for the property.

The fix for this is to detect in TypeScriptReflectionHost when a ts.Symbol
refers to a shorthand property, and to use the ts.TypeChecker method
getShorthandAssignmentValueSymbol() to resolve the value of the assignment
instead.

FW-1089 #resolve

Issues.Title: document pattern for replacing chains of resolves
Issues.Body:


# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
 This feature request is for @angular/router

### Description
The problem is that router.navigate automatically encodes a URL  ( using encodeURIComponent( .. )  I think),  but this encoding is not idempotent.
For example repeated encodes of a path with parameter segments will duplicate encoding of a '% '
Consequently, navigation from a path constructed from prior navigation will cause disaster when 
decodeURIComponent( .. ) is used to recover the parameter object .

### Describe the solution you'd like
An optional parameter to disable URL encoding.
Then the user can avoid this problem by encoding each parameter just once. 

This  parameter could be an option  in router.navigate,    (easy for a user to notice)

Alternatively a module option in
    RouterModule.forRoot(routes,
    {    enableTracing: true,
      initialNavigation: true,
      relativeLinkResolution: 'corrected',   // Fix Router BUG
      disableUrlEncoding: true                  //  Suggest something like this: but would need documentation
     }

### Describe alternatives you've considered
1.   navigateByUrl:   but I would prefer not to construct absolute URL's ( with possibly unexpected limitations) 
2.   Custom UrlSerializer:  but this seems unreasonably difficult for  an average user to investigate and implement.

Issues.Title: Add a way to easily reload a resolver
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
@angular/router


### Description

Happy path

I use the resolver to pre-fetch some data so when component is loaded I don't have things popping like xmas tree on the screen. All works fine, things are great, everybody is happy.

Sad path

I use the resolver to pre-fetch some data, api returns me any http error and no data. Things don't go as expected, I have no data to display, everybody is sad.

In this case I don't want to send the user to an error page, instead I want to load the same page, but customized with an error message and a reload button that will reload my resolver and maybe this time everything will work fine and people will be happy.

### Describe the solution you'd like

It would be great to have some way of forcing the route to reload its resolver. Something like activatedRoute.resolve()

### Describe alternatives you've considered

So I know that there are workarounds to the problem, but all come with some caveat, for example:

- we could change navigationStrategy to 'reload', but it would add a lot of extra work to avoid the parent to reload when user is navigating to a child.

- we could add a refresh param with the timestamp, but it would add an extra params and also would need to change the navigationStrategy, which would put us back on the previous bullet point issue.

There are few others, but all add a lot of extra steps. Which may be fine when we are talking about just one route of the entire app, but not fine when you have to do it in multiple routes. Which also generates a lot of boilerplate.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add a way to easily reload a resolver" (#28914)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): shim node events builtin for dev server
Issues.Body:
The dev server requires a node 'events' builtin shim to function.  The dev server as written only currently works with package managers that hoist the `events` shim package to an accessible location.  Hoisting is unfortunately not standardized and the assumption within the dev server will not hold true for all package managers. The actual code is only accessed when hmr is enabled which allows the 'events' import to be ignored in the non-hmr case.

Closes #13680

Issues.Title: Build and test all projects in the correct sequence following dependencies.
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [x] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
Angular CLI nowadays supports multiple projects per single workspace. This was an important improvement, however, I am still missing a smarter build command that would `build` all the projects in a correct sequence. And the same is applicable to `test` command.

**What does the correct sequence mean**
Usually in a bigger monorepo workspaces developed packages can have dependencies on one another, which means that simple alphabetical order of build/test will not work.

**Example**

```bash
Libraries & dependencies
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Library 1
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Library 3
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Library 2
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Library 3
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Library3
```

In the example above current sequence of `ng test` would be `Library 1 - Library 2 - Library 3`, but the correct sequence would be `Library 3 - Library 1 - Library 2`


### Describe the solution you'd like
Every project in a workspace already contains `package.json` (_obviously_). We could use `peerDependencies` to declare the dependencies between projects of the workspace. Then `build` and `test` commands would be able to detect the dependencies and build the libraries in the correct sequence.

I have written myself a node executable that does exactly that. Follows the dependency tree and builds the libraries in the correct sequence.
If that is something you see as a valuable addition to Angular CLI I would be more than happy to contribute.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
Currently, the only alternative is to write `ng build` commands in an npm script, which is practically unmaintainable in bigger workspaces.

Issues.Title: Mat-progress-bar should gradually appear and disappear, as per material.io spec
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
The material.io design spec for [progress indicators](https://material.io/design/components/progress-indicators.html#) has an ingenious solution to the problem of showing a progress bar that only appears for a fraction of a second. ([video](https://storage.googleapis.com/spec-host-backup/mio-design%2Fassets%2F1sSySgWKCC1qeSfWkBvSfI6X2CFnkpa2u%2F01-progress-intro.mp4))

**Spec:**
* When the progress indicator appears the height animates in from 0, so it gracefully appears without jumping. 
* When it disappears it animates height back to 0. 

Therefore a progress bar that is shown for only a few milliseconds may only reach a height of 1 or 2 pixels and be barely noticed. This is especially important when the progress bar represents a frequent operation with an unknown duration.

This behavior would not apply to all progress bar modes. Either a new mode `inactive` could be added, or an additional boolean value. 

`mode="(isBusy$ | async) ? 'indeterminate' : 'inactive'"`
`mode="indeterminate" isBusy="isBusy$ | async`

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?
It's in the spec, and it's very simple yet elegant way to solve the problem of something appearing and disappearing [suddenly](https://github.com/angular/material2/issues/8085). 

The spec shows exactly how a progress bar should work :-)

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Please don't suggest I make my own animation. This should be supported by the control.

Issues.Title: Transition out of ViewEncapsulation.None
Issues.Body:
This sort of falls in between a bug and a feature...
It is a bug on the Angular side, more of a feature request on material side..  

#### What is the expected behavior?

Material components should not be leaking styling to other components when routed. It is possible that contrasting styles/different themes are applied (see primary vs. secondary in material design https://material.io/design/color/the-color-system.html#color-theme-creation). We should be able to apply contrasting styles to material elements in different components. Material components should migrate out of ViewEncapsulation.None to prevent style leaking.

#### What is the current behavior?

A number of material elements use ViewEncapsulation.None (example: https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/master/src/lib/form-field/form-field.ts) . It is a known issue that this encapsulation mode leaks styling of the **from** component to the **to** component. See here: https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/16670

So let's say if you have black mat-inputs in Component A, and white mat-inputs in Component-B and you navigate from Component A to Component B, the inputs will falsely appear black. 

I believe that the ViewEncapsulation.None mode is not an absolute necessity for material components and its use should be deprecated. 

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

+ Create component A with the default theme
+ Create component B and override/change the styling of material elements 
+ Navigate using angular router from B to A.
+ The default styling will be overwritten 

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

I believe the lower versions are effected as well but my current versions are:

Angular 7.2.6
Material 7.3.1
OS: MacOS Sierra
TS: 3.1.1

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Transition out of ViewEncapsulation.None" (#15274)

You will see that it wobbles by pixel left and right. In this same StackBlitz there's `(scrolledIndexChange)="onItemChange($event)"` on the scroll viewport.
